selected_quotes: WTF? 'microbiome evolved mechanisms specific to mortality of senescent individuals among early humans' @mbiojournal
Microbes played a significant role in human evolution and the source paper in mBio
I honestly do not understand the 'Host Demise as a Beneficial Function of Indigenous Microbiota in Human Hosts' paper
Two interesting microbiome papers in this week's
Commensal bacteria are friends, then foes to keep population in check.

citation.abstract: The age structure of human populations is exceptional among animal species. Unlike with most species, human juvenility is extremely extended, and death is not coincident with the end of the reproductive period. We examine the age structure of early humans with models that reveal an extraordinary balance of human fertility and mortality. We hypothesize that the age structure of early humans was maintained by mechanisms incorporating the programmed death of senescent individuals, including by means of interactions with their indigenous microorganisms. First, before and during reproductive life, there was selection for microbes that preserve host function through regulation of energy homeostasis, promotion of fecundity, and defense against competing high-grade pathogens. Second, we hypothesize that after reproductive life, there was selection for organisms that contribute to host demise. While deleterious to the individual, the presence of such interplay may be salutary for the overall host population in terms of resource utilization, resistance to periodic diminutions in the food supply, and epidemics due to high-grade pathogens. We provide deterministic mathematical models based on age-structured populations that illustrate the dynamics of such relationships and explore the relevant parameter values within which population viability is maintained. We argue that the age structure of early humans was robust in its balance of the juvenile, reproductive-age, and senescent classes. These concepts are relevant to issues in modern human longevity, including inflammation-induced neoplasia and degenerative diseases of the elderly, which are a legacy of human evolution.
citation.title: Host Demise as a Beneficial Function of Indigenous Microbiota in Human Hosts

news.title: Did Microbes Shape the Human Lifespan?
news.summary: The microbes that live in and on humans may have evolved to preferentially take down the elderly in the population, a new computer model suggests. Such a microbial bias may also have kept the first human populations more stable and resilient to upheavals,

news.title: Commensal bacteria were critical shapers of early human populations
news.summary: Using mathematical modeling, researchers have shown that commensal bacteria that cause problems later in life most likely played a key role in stabilizing early human populations. The finding offers an explanation as to why humans co-evolved with microbes
